To my L. T
re
r 25 Sep
t
95.
It is now 10 dayes and more,
t
the Deputies of
e
States,
w
c
were sent to take advise w
t
Co. Maurice
and
e
Councell,
returned to
e Hage. And since I have observed
t
both they
and
e rest have bin divers times togither to consult upon the
matter, in so much as I suppose,
t
either they before this,
would have sent for me unto their college, or deputed some to
tell me to wat effect they had resolved. But being secretly
informed,
at
ey had varyed in opinions, and surceased for
e time
to deliberat upon it, I re
q
sted to have audience in their
publicke meeting: where I put them in remembrance of
all
e course of my
ceeding in this negociation, how long
it had bin sinc e
e matter was
posed, how many l
re
s her M
ie
had written unto th
e
, how great occ
ao
ns were p
nt
ed
t
she might wordily disdayne this long delaying of their answear
w
t
such other alleg
ao
ns as fitted
t
argum
e
t. Whereuto their
speeches returned were so vehem
e
t, and earnest, and full of
solemne
testations, as I can not call to minde,
t
I have
fol.292v
heard them at any time doe
e like heeretofore. For of all
e troublesome accid
e
ts, of w
c
they had bin partakers since
e
union of their Provinces, theie had not any, at any time yet,
either busyed them longer, or grieved them more, or caryed
so much danger, if it were not well c
o
ducted, as this proposal
of her M
ie
. For w
c
they urged me exceedingly to move her
M
ie
to c
o
sider
e c
o
position of their governm
e
t,
e humor of
e people,
e state of their affaires, w
c
in a cause of this nature
would by no meanes admitte any speedier dispatche. They
had sent, they sayd, of purpose to
e councell of estate to re
q
e
st
advise w
c
had already bin reported by theyr Deputies unto th
e
but it proved so defective, as they were nothing ayded by it,
for w
c
they had resolved to sende theyr l
re
s out of hand to
re
q
st theyr
p
sence at
e Hage, so
t
they hoped very shortly
to come in conference together, and then to grow to some
c
o
clusion. W
c
was
e effect of all theyr answear, though
I did my best endevor to drawe them by
suasion to some p
nt
resolution. For my privat opinion of
e sequel of this
matter, it is no other in no respect, then I have formerly
declared by my l
re
s to yo
r
L. For there is nothing to be
heard but c
o
plaintes of all handes,
at I may say in this cause,
as I could never yet in any
t
touched her M
ie
t
of all tha
[t]
heeretofore I have found in this c
o
try well affected unto
her, I doe not know so much as one
t
will affourd
e lest
ayde, or any token of allowance or favour in this matter.
